185971682.review: multiplayer doesn't work due to buggy coding...firewall won't let you play online even with permissions through firewall....only solution is to go into the games files and change values, and this only works once..solid no.  this seems to be a persistent issue in a lot of "multiplayer games". we all just need to let devs know that like any other industry you can't release junk and get paid for it

185965010.review: Fun in the way that all ARPGs are fun (the little dopamine hits, the random reinforcement, offered by loot drops), but shallow customization compared to Diablo II, Grim Dawn, or Path of Exile 2. There are only four classes, and they each have three rather small skill trees, with few synergies between skills. There isn't much room for theorycrafting or innovation here. The cartoonish aesthetic, and the limited options for customizing a character's appearance, only add to this feeling of over-simplicity. This game feels strictly less interesting and less rewarding than Diablo II or Grim Dawn or Path of Exile 2 to me.

185912191.review: I was looking for a game that was similar to Diablo in play style, character advancement, and customization and this fits the bill.  I'm glad I searched for games similar to Diablo and this one came up.  Though I have yet to explore the multi-player mode and extended play that comes after you finish the standard plot, I anticipate that both will continue to provide challenge, fun, and continued development and customization of my character(s).

185901822.review:
Honestly this is an on-the-fence review but... given the sheer amount of games out there to play, I'm defaulting to no. The quest system has me wishing I needed to use my brain more but at the same time I'm dodging using my brain to figure out my build because the build system is just not very conducive to experimentation. I tried twice to figure out a build, got to a point at the end of Act 1 where it clearly wasn't working, and ended up relying on a build guide. Not being able to respect anything except the 3 previous points really hinders the process of working things out on my own, as does the fact that you have no ability to grind for XP or loot until you completely beat the game once. So if the build you guessed at can't get to endgame, you're only option is to start over. The itemization is pretty weird, too. The number of times I get a thing that's item level 40 but I can't wear it until I'm 52 is very annoying, especially when it's weaker than something I'm already wearing.

It's a pity because the combat is reasonably fun, if cartoony. Back to Grim Dawn.

185835594.review: Game is pretty good, fluid, a little weird at times but not a bad pickup. Only reason I'm giving it a negative is because the Studio sold out so their tech support doesn't exist anymore, which means if you're like me and my friend who got this game for co-op, you're SOL. If you run into auth issues, theres a chance you may never get to play multiplayer period because the only troubleshooting you can go off of is Reddit forums or other forum posts that are 10 years old.

185729290.review:
As simple as these games are, there are exceedingly satisfying.
If you prefer simple but deep customization and skill progression (i.e. controlling stat growth), as well as snappy but simple click = 1 attack gameplay, Torchlight and Torchlight II are easy to recommend.
If you want more complicated skill interactions from an RPG, then it may not be the move.

184464156.review:
Torchlight 2 is, to say the least, a decent idea. A nice little package with tons of content and inspirations from previous hack and slash games like Diablo. 

However, while the premise of this whole package is interesting, the contents are blander than a boxed pair of socks... And you don't even get to stay warm with them.

The gameplay is rough. Very rough. While there are tons of skills and interesting ways to build, the game forces you to stay on those paths. You can only reroll your last 3 points worth of skills, and that's it. No experimentation other than having to replay the game all over again.

Not only that, but even the interface and controls are clunky as all heck. For example, who in their right state of mind would make a channel ability target a monster, but also not locking the player in, so whenever you press the ability, the character just does milliseconds worth of damage and then just runs into the danger? You have to deliberately hold your ground with Shift, then press the channel skill button to have the skill behave how it's intended to be used.

The pet system is interesting, except when it just doesn't do anything worth talking about. The main usage of the pets are 1. Tanking for a few seconds, because the enemies will shred through them no matter what you do, 2. Buying a consumable just in case you forgot while in town, 3. Holding trash in inventory and selling it by making it unable to be used for a few minutes. Otherwise, the pet system is pretty pointless in the 20 hours I slogged through.

Looting isn't that much more fun either. Fighting monsters felt sluggish and unrewarding. The environments are bland, and the presentation mediocre. I played a bit in Veteran, but never managed to reach more than level 20 out of boredom, in the multiple tries I gave to it.

If you're really desperate to play a Diablo-like, eh, give it a try if it's on heavy sale. But do NOT expect anything that made them good in this game. You'll be very sorry if you do.

184444916.review:

184431196.review:
One of the best ARPGs ever made and quite possibly one of the most underrated ones. I’m glad I’m writing this review so late after its release so that I can compare it to even more modern releases like PoE2. 
I feel TL2 has achieved the sense of secrets and exploration better than any other ARPG, even better than PoE2. The feel of the game is great, items and crafting is nice, the fact you have a pet to go to town to buy and sell items while you continue playing, and the gambling, oooh the gambling is one of the best ever. 
I like the art and boss fights the characters and the mods outdo themselves and easily add hundreds of hours of gameplay and might help with the journey of completionisting this game
Overall score 8/10

184355451.review: This is the perfect ARPG. finding items feels rewarding through out the entire game. You can actually finish the game and finish your characters. Most ARPG's it's not even possible to finish one character because the game loop never ends. My only issues are that the multiplayer sucked, and the story writing sucked. The end game could have been a tad more challenging too perhaps. That being said this game is still better than almost every other ARPG that has ever existed. I would put maybe only skyrim above this one.

183787176.review:
Worth about 20 hours or so of play, but lacking any real challenge at least on normal difficulty. We played in 3-player co-op and I think I used fewer than ten health potions throughout the game, despite having hundreds. I did focus on having lots of armor, though, so maybe that's why. Friends died several times later in the game due to apparent one-shots, but I suffered no such difficulties. I may have died once, if at all.

I played an engineer and found the abilities lacking. Granted, I only invested heavily in a few skills as I'm not very good at managing large numbers of abilities, but it was a little bit boring to be honest. I just kept an eye on my health orb, made sure my bubble was up to absorb damage, and popped a self heal in the event my health dropped at all. Rinse, repeat. Bosses failed to change things up.

The story is on the weak side and I only half paid attention to it: BBEG is trying to do something bad, so chase him down (i.e., navigate world areas and defeat the bosses left in his wake) and ultimately catch up and defeat him just before he can do the bad thing. The details seem kind of convoluted and random, but I get the feeling that story is largely secondary in games of this genre.

My biggest complaint is, I think, a problem of the genre: ability spam. It's all flashy effects (especially with more players) and lots of baddies on screen at one time and it becomes a bit of a mess that's hard to decipher. You don't really end up paying much attention to what's going on onscreen or who you're currently attacking, just choose a new target if the current one dies, occasionally trigger an offensive ability if you're feeling spicy, and watch your health. That seems to be the way other games (Diablo, et al.) play out as well and it's just doesn't seem that much fun to me, though I'm hardly an expert and maybe other genre staples are more interesting.

It's an okay game, just nothing remarkable. If you don't already own it from the many bundles it's been in, you can buy it for just a few dollars on sale. For that price, and with friends, it's worthy of a playthrough. Just don't set your expectations too high.
